DOC.HEAD: Anti-Noriega Military Prisoners Take Over Prison

Editors Note: The following is from pool dispatches filed by Steven Komarow of The Associated Press, Kathy Lewis of the Houston Post, Kevin Merida of The Dallas Morning News, Bill Clayton of the Houston Chronicle and Dick Thompson of Time magazine.
DOC.TEXT: A group of Panamanian prisoners, including a military officer involved in the ill-fated coup in October, took over an island penitentiary and asked for help from the United States, U.S. military officials said Saturday. The prison, which had been run by loyalists to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is on an island off Panama's Pacific coast about 60 miles from the capital. U.S. officials said the prisoner revolt was led by a man identified only as ``Major Pajaro'' who was said to be one of the leaders of the unsuccessful coup against Noriega on Oct. 3. No other details of the prison revolt were available. Meanwhile, U.S. military officials said small bands of Noriega supporters were continuing harassing attacks in the capital. Lt. Col. Jerry Marguila, spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command, said the hit-and-run Noriega loyalists are ``increasing their activities of harassing attacks with small arms and mortar fire, threatening the civilian population, and hostage-taking.'' When pressed for specific numbers, Marguila replied ``I don't have in my mind an increase in numbers between today and yesterday of dignity-battalion efforts. It's just that they are becoming more of a concern, because they are taking more of our time as opposed to the PDF (Panama Defense Force).'' Marguila said the task of the U.S. troops is turning from conventional warfare to counterterrorism and police duties. The U.S. military spokesman said ``armed bandits'' continue to roam many parts of Panama City and that looting has moved from shopping districts into some upperclass residential neighborhoods where residents have been arming themselves. Marguila said that with the neutralizing of the PDF by the U.S. military the country is without an adequate police force to deal with the lawlessness. ``The PDF was involved in just about every nook and cranny of the government. Since that element is gone, there is a void and a gap, especially in the police force ... and that is something we need to rebuild,'' the spokesman said.
